title: Chasing Curation: How I Scored a 50% Success Rate
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started
  • About
  • Challenge
  • Write Now
  • Submit
  • Slack
  • Join

Chasing Curation: How I Scored a 50% Success Rate

The Quest For the Medium Grail

Elle Fredine
Apr 3

Here it is, folks — I’ve cracked the curation formula! Finally — the secret of how to achieve instant curation success — explained here and now. And while I’m at it, can I sell you a nice bridge? Your own island paradise for a buck-fifty?

Okay, maybe I don’t have it completely in the bag. And I’m certainly not a guru or “How-to-Medium” expert.

I can only tell you what’s worked for me. But I’m currently writing at a 50% curation rate, and I’ve managed to scrape into the 7.5 percent making over $100 a month since my third month here. And working hard to improve.

It doesn’t matter how you dress it up. Success on any platform takes work — hard work, concentrated effort. And here’s some of the best advice on writing I’ve ever found — writing anywhere, writing anything:

Write angry;
Take a hard stance;
Say what isn’t being said — give me your slant on it;
Don’t lecture — just talk to me, like friends over a coffee;
But know what you’re talking about — show me your personal interest in this, show me where it touches you;
Know that people will not always agree;
But write anyway — write as if your life depends on it.

But first, learn the basics — learn how to use the platform. This is true anywhere. You have to learn how the interface works; the terms of engagement (the rules — what you can and can’t do); all the little and not-so-little tricks and tips.

Which is what the <HELP> section is for, and forums, whether on the platform, on FaceBook, or a dedicated Slack channel. Places where you can meet other creatives, share joys and points of pain, ask and answer questions, give and receive support.

But once you have the basics under your belt — you’ve learned how to craft a decent article/blog post; you’ve done a lot of reading and you think you’ve got some idea of what works and what doesn’t — so, now what? How do you take it to the next level?

Well, first, the big buzz is “content”, “topics”, “content”, “topics.” And rightly so. Without an interesting topic and good content, your readers are going to leave pretty quickly. They’ll vote with their mouse or a swipe of the finger if you’re not delivering either one.

“Readers are not sheep, and not every pen tempts them.” — Vladimir Nabokov

Then, the next item on the list of importance is “headlines” — and it’s true. Shy of click-bait and extreme over-promising, a provocative title can win you a lot of attention. But remember: your title is a contract you make with your reader.

You offer something: “How to Eat Sh*t and Not Die.” Then you make good on your promise: you deliver the article in your title.

“The link between the life and the work is one of the things we’re curious about and look for when we pick up the latest book by a favorite author.” — James Shapiro
“I’m not so arrogant to think I’m the only guide someone needs … but I might be the guide that someone needs.” — Laura Anne Gilman

The big buzz right now is Curation

Curation is a huge topic among newer Medium writers and among not-so-new writers looking to increase their readership and achieve success. Curation is the new holy grail — the surefire way to succeed on Medium.

Hang around the writing group forums and feeds, and sooner, probably than later, you’ll see a question about curation: What is it? How do I get some?

And there’s a lot of speculation on how to achieve this Holy Grail. There’s an explanation of what they’re looking for in the <HELP> section. It’s not a mystery. It’s actually pretty straightforward if a bit ambiguous in spots.

The problem comes in when we try to unpack the criteria. Why did this piece get curated when this one didn’t? We’re trying to “get” their angle, figure out the “formula.” Because then, we can do it again and again, right?

Well, it doesn’t work that way. The curators are charged with selecting solid pieces in any genre and promoting them. The best they can find at any given time that fit their criteria. Simple.

They are looking for good articles, with a catchy headline, solid info and a strong voice, mainly error-free, that they believe will grab and hold a reader’s interest.

Some current thoughts on curation — things I’ve found which don’t make a damn bit of difference, in my experience:

1. The publication you write for makes no difference

In my experience. I find curation depends more on the individual piece than on which publication it’s in. Or what the topic is. Or the size of the pub.

I’ve had articles curated in nine of the publications for which I write. Two of the publications are brand-new ones, and the rest more established. Some are smaller pubs, but I’ve had pieces curated in The Startup and in The Writing Cooperative. Yay, and thank-you.

I don’t know that you will be curated more for your self-published articles, than for articles in a publication. I suspect not.

I‘ve written for several sites where everything was “self-published.” I know how hard it is to gain readers and views when you’re starting out. So, when I started here, I decided to submit to already established publications to get more eyes on my work — “speed-dating” to meet more readers more quickly. So far, it’s helped a lot, and I’m so grateful for it.

2. The genre (the type of article) makes little difference

Again, in my experience, I’ve had both fiction and non-fiction curated, including poetry, and photography. The only constant for me has been most of the curated articles are a minimum of a four-minute read, and most of my poems aren’t that long. Nor is the one which was curated.

Yes, it’s harder to have a fiction piece or a poem curated. Take a look at the topics on Medium’s main page and work out the stats for how many articles are published in each topic. This is one of the best sites I’ve found for fiction writers, but overall, historically, non-fiction articles do better online.

3. The tags you use make little difference

The number beside the tags shows how many articles are published on that topic. Medium curators don’t use tags to decide whether they will promote an article for distribution. But they may promote/distribute your article in different topics/tags to the ones you chose — topics/tags they believe are a better fit, perhaps — the topics in which your article will be distributed.

I had one article distributed in four tags — “There’s Gotta Be an App for That” distributes in Women, Work, Humour, Equality. And they were tags I’d chosen already. But when the curators chose different tags for my article or story, I often add their tags, replacing ones I’ve already chosen.

I’ve had older pieces curated — which was a nice surprise! I’ve gone back through my stats page and noted which articles were curated, and a few have popped up as curated well after their publication date.

Perhaps some kind soul recommended the piece to the Medium editors. Maybe somebody found it languishing in their virtual wastebasket. Who knows? Sometimes it can take a while for one of your articles to go through the review process. I’ve had pieces take several days: up to a week, for one article.

And, we can recommend our own pieces for review — draw a deserving article to their attention. But I’d hesitate to start spamming the Medium editors every time you believe your deserving article was overlooked.

But here’s the bottom line: Curation is all about the individual piece

It really all depends on the article and the headline. The curators are looking for quality pieces they believe readers will want to read.

Let me repeat that. They are looking for good articles, with solid info and a strong hook, written in a clear, authentic voice, mainly error-free, and which they believe will grab and hold a reader’s interest.

No tricks, no wiggles, no formulas. Guidelines — yes. Formulas — no.

So follow the advice at the beginning of this article. It works. It will help you take your work to the next level.

  • Write angry; okay, you literally don’t have to be angry all the time. Please. Besides, it’s bad for your blood pressure. But you have to be passionate about every topic you write on. Because if you’re not passionately involved why should I be?
  • Take a hard stance; say what you mean and mean what you say, and don’t waffle. Be brave. And remember, you can’t fight on both sides of a cause, even if you can and do point out the merits of both.
  • Say what isn’t being said — give me your slant on it; tell me something different; make me see it in a way I’ve never thought about; show me your personal interest, where it touches you. Make me hear your voice.
  • Don’t lecture — don’t preach — just talk to me, like friends over a coffee.
  • But know what you’re talking about — don’t just bang on about your opinion — back it up with a few facts and examples.
  • Know that people will not always agree; there will always be some of us with a different opinion; be prepared for push-back, but don’t back down.
  • And write — write anyway. Write as if your life depends on it. ’Cause, guess what — it does.
  • Medium
  • Writing
  • Self Improvement
  • Curation
  • Writing Tips

  • Elle Fredine

    Medium member since Aug 2018

    West-Coaster, born and bred; northerner at heart; writing online since 2008; I have green eyes and I love coffee.

  • The Writing Cooperative

    Helping each other write better.

title_html: Chasing Curation: How I Scored a 50% Success Rate
